EXISTING STRUCTURES
─────────────────────────────
### Shared Smelting Furnaces Automation Network
Consists of:
• Two stone furnaces – one at Position(x=0.0, y=0.0) and another at Position(x=5.0, y=0.0) – each paired with nearby burner inserters and output chests.
• Interconnecting transport belts that route materials between furnaces and adjacent logistics components.

### Iron Ore Mining Automation Setup
Consists of:
• A burner mining drill at Position(x=-15.0, y=-50.0) equipped with associated burner inserters and a wooden chest at Position(x=-13.5, y=-51.5).
• Transport belt links that convey the mined iron ore to processing areas.

### Automation Research Lab
Consists of:
• A laboratory structure receiving automation-science-pack inputs (currently in a no-power state).
• A supporting network of small electric poles interconnecting the lab with available power sources.

### Water Supply System for Power Generation with Updated Steam Engine Placement
Consists of:
• A boiler at Position(x=8.0, y=20.5) featuring connection points at Position(x=8.5, y=18.5) and Position(x=8.5, y=22.5); its fluid box holds 200 units of water.
• Steam engines intended for power generation:
  – Pre‐existing units at Positions (1.5, 13.5), (13.5, 14.5), (19.5, 14.5), (13.5, 17.5), (17.5, 20.5) and (11.5, 20.5)
  – Newly placed unit at Position(x=22.5, y=18.5) (successfully set in Step 397)
• An offshore pump at Position(x=0.5, y=30.5)
• Multiple pipe groups interconnecting the boiler, steam engines, and pump.
Note: Subsequent re-attempts to place an additional steam engine adjacent to the boiler (using directions DOWN, RIGHT, and LEFT with varying spacing and a buildable-area check) were unsuccessful. No new engine was added to the structure, and efforts later shifted toward crafting a replacement – which also faced resource-related setbacks.

ERROR TIPS
────────────
• Steam Engine Placement Failures (Directional & Spacing Issues)
 – Multiple attempts using direction DOWN (with spacing values 1 and 2), RIGHT, and LEFT failed due to collisions with pre-existing pipe layouts, nearby generators, trees, or other blocking entities.
  Tip: Always pre-check candidate coordinates and verify clearances (using buildability or bounding box feedback) before issuing placement commands. Adjust spacing and direction to avoid collisions.

• Misuse of Buildable Area Attributes
 – An error occurred when accessing the center of the buildable area (“'Position' object is not callable”), indicating that the center property was called as a function.
  Tip: Access object properties correctly (e.g., using .center without parentheses if it is a property) to avoid type errors.

• Crafting and Inventory Deficiencies
 – Attempts to craft a steam engine failed due to insufficient sub-ingredients – notably, the inability to automatically produce enough iron-plates (the recipe requires a crafting machine or furnace smelting) and later, an insufficient count of iron-plates (required amounts of 2–3 per engine).
  Tip: Ensure that production chains for intermediate items (such as iron-plates, iron-gear wheels, and pipes) are operating at sufficient capacity and that the inventory meets the recipe requirements before initiating a craft command.

• General API and Collision Feedback
 – Error messages indicate that placement functions rejected positions because of both terrain restrictions (e.g., water) and collisions with other entities.
  Tip: Incorporate pre-placement clearance checks and validate candidate positions using environmental feedback prior to placement attempts.
